titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. We had a calm all the morning; but at noon a fair and fresh breeze sprung up.— At half past four in the afternoon we made the land at the false cape; near cape Hinlopen.— We came up within two leagues of the light-house before dark, but as no pilot appeared we were obliged to stand off during the night.

2. Early this morning we approached again within a small distance of Cape Henlopen; but the wind dying away, and the tide having turned against us, we anchor’d off the cape at nine o’clock. At 2 in the afternoon we got under weigh again; having the ship at first tow’d by the boat— A light breeze however soon sprung up and we came within the cape; waiting all this time with no small anxiety for a pilot.— At length at about 3 in the afternoon, Mr: M. Mane made his appearance in that capacity— We came about twenty miles up the bay before dark, when our breeze and tide both failing we came to anchor.

3. Early this morning we again weigh’d anchor, and with a faint and irregular breeze, proceeded slowly up Delaware bay— In the afternoon at Port Penn a custom house officer came on board. We made a progress of about 70 miles up the bay and river in the course of the day, and anchored about 20 miles below the city at night— Newcastle and Wilmington, the points where the views from the river are most beautiful we passed in the evening, and could not enjoy their fine prospects.

4. At 7 in the morning we pass’d Chester and at the Lazaretto twelve miles below the city were visited by the health officer; the wind was very light, and the weather blazing with heat as it has been these three days— About noon, we landed at the wharf in Philadelphia; where we were received by my brother who had just been informed of our arrival— He had engaged lodgings for us at Mrs: Roberts’s— Walnut street N: 139. and went immediately with us to them.— We remained at home the rest of the day which was extremely warm.— Wrote in the Evening to the Secy: of State, and to my father.

5. The weather continues excessively warm— A number of gentlemen called in the course of the day to visit us—Major Jackson, Mr: Ingersoll and his son, Mr: Meredith, Mr: Read, Mr: Peters &c. Mrs: Rutter called to see Mrs: Adams. We were obliged to confine ourselves almost entirely to the house.

6. Went to church this morning to Christ church where we heard a sermon preach’d by bishop White— Intended to have gone this afternoon to meeting but were prevented by the great heat. Took tea at Mr: Rutter’s. Dr: Rush called and spent an hour with us in the evening.— Several other gentlemen called in the course of the day. Mrs: Quincy to see Mrs: A.

7. We went into the country this afternoon with Dr: Rush, to his house about two miles out of town— Took tea there and returned in the Evening. His two eldest sons, John and Richard were there— Mrs: Rush and her daughter are absent, in New Jersey. My brother was engaged at the Supreme Court of the State.

8. Went this morning and engaged for Mrs: A— the stage to Baltimore, which is to leave this town Saturday morning at eight o’clock— Called with her at noon upon Mrs: Tudor who is at Francis’s Hotel.— She has a son with her in ill health; and two others left her this morning to return to Boston.

9. This afternoon we went about 6 miles out of town to Bishop White’s, and took tea with his two daughters— He himself is gone to attend a general convention of the episcopal clergy at Trenton— We met there General M’Pherson and his two daughters, Mrs: Lewis, Mrs: Rawls &c— We came home between 8 and 9. in the evening— Dr: Rush call’d upon us.

10. Dined this day with Dr: Rush. Mr: George Clymer; a young Mr: Biddle, Dr: and my brother formed the company with Dr: Rush’s sons. Took tea at Major Jackson’s— Dennie spent the forenoon with me, and we had much conversation together.

11. In the course of last night the weather which has been at a point of extreme heat ever since the first day of the month, changed very suddenly to cool, or almost cold— It affected Mrs: A. much— Yet though quite unwell she went out with me to Mr: Francis’s— Where we dined. Mr: Willing, Mrs: Francis’s father, Several of her brothers, Major Jackson and Dr: Proudfit were there. We came home early— Mrs: Rutter called upon Mrs: A— who was very ill— Mr: Vaughan and Dr: Rush called and took leave of me. Dennie was with me again part of the morning.

12. At 8 this morning Mrs: A— with her child, Epps and Whitcomb sat out in the stage for Baltimore. It is the first time we have been separated since our marriage— I parted from her and my child with pain and no small concern and anxiety— At noon I took passage in the New-York stage, where was Mr: Shaw, a young man whom I saw some years ago in London, and who has now just arrived from India; and six other passengers— We dined at Bristol, and there took a lady who went on with us to Trenton. The night came on quite cold, and we were just after coming out of Princeton detained a full hour, by the loss of one of our passenger’s trunks, which was however at length recovered.

13. We rode all night— At Brunswick 60 miles from Philadelphia, we supp’d at two in the morning. We ought to have arrived there at 11. last night.— I added here to my cloathing; by way of substitute for a surtout which I had not.— From Brunswick to Woodbridge ten miles we were driven very fast— But arrived too late— The stage had gone on just before we arrived, and our driver was obliged to carry us on with the same carriage and horses 16 miles further to Newark—6 miles before this, at Elizabeth-Town one of our passengers left us— And I myself parted from the remainder at Newark. Here Coll: Smith’s mother resides with her youngest and only unmarried daughter Nancy; and my sister Smith with her little daughter Caroline are with her on a visit. At about 9 this morning I went from Gifford’s Inn to her house where I breakfasted and pass’d the remainder of the day.— My sister received me with her own warm, unaffected and unpretending cordiality— And I heartily rejoyce to find her in good health. Her daughter is six years old, and therefore born since I left this country in 1794— I went to meeting with them in the forenoon, and heard Dr: M’Whorter preach a communion sermon— Meanwhile Coll: Smith came out from New-York to which place he return’d in the evening— Overcome with the fatigues & cold weather of the last night I slept from 4 this afternoon untill my sister wak’d me at 8 in the evening to sup— At 10 I return’d to bed.

14. At nine this morning my sister took me with her to New-York; to which she returns for the winter— We found the Coll: ready to receive us at Powles hook— We reach’d the city soon after 11. I call’d at Mr: M’Cormick’s to deliver Pitcairn’s letter—but neither he nor Mr: Rogers are in town— After dinner I went with Coll: Smith to visit Mr: Burr, Vice-President of the United States and Mr: Edward Livingston, Mayor of the City— Neither of them were at home.— Both return’d the visit, this evening.— Mr: Burr I saw—Mr: Clarkson spent part of the eveg: at the Colls:
In our walk we went to see the steam engine, lately erected to supply the city with water. An ingenious and complicated machine— There I met Dr: Brown, who recollected having seen me more than twenty years ago, at Leyden— We likewise went over the Mount-Vernon, and Vauxhall gardens— Places for summer amusements— Sat up till midnight conversing with the Coll: after supper.

15. Chilly and rainy morning. The Coll: took me with him to dine at Mr: Brockholst Livingston’s. There was a company of fifteen persons, apparently of various political opinions—the centre of whose association seem’d to be the whist and brag tables— The subjects of conversation were politics—money transactions—growse shooting, and gaming— I came home early in the evening, with the Coll:— Play’d chess with him & with my sister.

16. Went this morning down upon Crane Wharf, and engaged a passage on board the Fame packet, Captin Justen, for Providence— To sail as soon as the wind will permit— As I was returning, found Mr: M’Cormick had come home— Dined with him—Judge Lawrence, Mr: Bell, and Mr: Boyle were there.— Found Miss Brown at tea with my sister in the evening. Took a walk with them afterwards, into Broadway.

17. Call’d at Crane wharf to enquire whether the packet would sail this day, but found it would be detained by the wind— Read St: John’s new journey in Pennsylvania and New-York. Dined at Mr: Burr’s. Mr: Edward Livingston, P. Edwards, Captain M’Neal, Mr: Williamson, Mr: Allen, Mr: Gahn, Mr: Dana and Mr: Tidyman, whom I saw sometime ago were of the company. As was Captn: Ellery.— I left the table and came home early to pass the evening with my sister—Mr: & Mrs: Clarkson were here. Play’d chess with my sister.

18. Call’d in the forenoon at Crane wharf, but the Captain did not think of sailing till to-morrow. I return’d and pass’d the remainder of the forenoon, reading St: John’s book— At about 3 o’clock in the afternoon Captain Justin call’d at Coll: Smith’s to inform me he should sail in about an hour— I dined, and immediately went on board the Packet— Coll: Smith accompanied me to the wharf. At half past four, the passengers had all got on board and we sailed, with fair weather and almost a total calm. About sunset we got through hell-gate— In the night there sprung up a light and favourable breeze.

19. Our passengers are Mr: Myers and his son, of Norfolk. he formerly resided at Amsterdam; where I saw him in the year 1783. Mr: & Mrs: Rogers of the island of St. Croix. Mr: Power of Providence. Dr: Senter of Newport, a young man lately arrived from England—another Virginian whose name I did not discover, and some others— We had a fair wind, and the finest weather possible; and landed at Newport at 1/2 past 9 this evening. Most of the other passengers went to Mrs: Aliny’s— I lodg’d at Townsend’s.

20. It being Sunday we found some difficulty in getting a passage up to Providence— None of the regular packets would go— Those here are all engaged loading a ship in the harbour; at length we all took passage in a trading sloop, from Albany, loaded with boards— Left the wharf at 1/2 past 11. The wind soon failed us, and we did not get up the river untill after Sunset— We had several additional passengers. Among the rest Mr: Bayard of Philadelphia— Most of them left the vessel
four miles below Providence opposite Patuxet, and went into a two-mast boat, which was sailing about the river— I remained on board, and got ashore about half an hour after them. Walk’d round the town with the passengers in the evening. Afterwards with Mr: Bayard, who recognized me, as having seen me formerly in England and at Boston— We lodg’d at Aldrich’s—Mr: Bayard and I in one chamber.

21. Mr: Bayard parted from us here, as he is going on to Philadelphia— We took the stage from Providence to Boston, and set out at 1/2 past eight in the morning. Mr: Myers & his son, Mr: and Mrs: Rogers, and five other passengers, in all eleven, in one stage— Another stage left Providence at the same time— The day was excessively warm— We dined at Walpole, where we found five regiments of Militia mustering for a training day to-morrow— At Dedham I met General Elliot and my old friend Frazier, his aid de camp, going on to the review— In Roxbury street I left the stage, and took a horse and chaise in which at 9 in the evening I reached my fathers house at Quincy— Here I had the inexpressible delight of finding once more my parents, after an absence of seven years— This pleasure would have been unalloyed but for the feeble and infirm state of my mother’s health— My parents received me with a welcome of the tenderest affection.

22. I had the satisfaction of spending this day almost entirely with my parents— Dr: Tufts called, in the forenoon.— In the afternoon I walk’d out with my father upon his farm, which has during my absence been much altered and improved— Louisa Smith is still in the family; and my mother has with her my brother Charles’s eldest daughter Susan, a fine child, about 5 years old.

23. My uncle Cranch call’d here on his way to Boston. Mr: Jos: Hall came out with William Shaw from town to see me; as did my friend Gardner from Milton— My uncle Adams came & spent part of the Evening with us. I went with my father to see Mr: Whitney the minister of the parish; but he was not at home— My Aunt Cranch & Mrs: Perkins call’d to see my mother this afternoon.

24. Mr: J. Forbes, my old classmate called to see me this morning— I went to Boston; and at Milton, finding Mr: Gardner, just going there too, persuaded him to take a seat in the chaise with me— Call’d in Boston, at Mr: W. Smith’s, at Mr: B. Shaw’s at Dr: Welsh’s; and saw a great number of my old friends and acquaintance— Dined at Mr: Smith’s— My fellow passenger from New-York Mr: Myers was there, with his son, Mr: J. C. Jones, Mr: J. Codman, Mr: Gorham, Mr: Brooks, and some others— Gardner return’d with me, and I stop’d a few minutes at his house.— Saw Mrs: Gardner— When I got home, found Mr: Boylston Adams, call’d to see me.

25. Went with my mother to Mr: Cranch’s, and call’d upon Mr: G. Apthorp who now resides here. Afterwards went with my father to see my uncle Quincy, who at an age nearly approaching ninety, is at present dangerously ill— This evening Whitcomb arrived, and I received letters—one from my wife, from which I learn she and the child had reached Washington safely and in good health— Mr: Beale and Mr: D. Greenleaf spent part of the Evening here.

26. Whitcomb went into Boston again this morning. Dr: Tufts and his lady, and Miss E. Smith dined at my father’s— W. Shaw came from Boston this evening— Dr: Tufts gave me the papers and documents he had of my property here— Pass’d the day chiefly in reading and writing.

27. Went to meeting twice— Heard Mr: Whitney preach— My uncle Adams dined with us— W. Shaw and I went and pass’d part of the Evening at Mr: Greenleaf’s— Mr: Beale was there— I wrote a letter to my brother, and some other things.

28. Went to Boston this morning with W. Shaw. Met T. Amory, Callender, and several other of my friends coming out to visit me at Quincy.— Call’d at Mr: Smith’s store—then on J. Hall; and paid several visits— Made enquiries for a house &c— Dined at Dr: Welsh’s— Continued making visits untill 5 o’clock, when, with Whitcomb I return’d to Quincy.

29. Dr: Tufts call’d in the forenoon, and I came to a settlement of accounts with him. Mr: Quincy died this day at about 12 o’clock. My mother with Mrs: Cranch went down to his house— I spent part of the Evening at Mr: Cranch’s— Bathed this morning.

30. Dr: Tufts and Mrs: Cranch were here this morning. I went into Boston with Louisa Smith— Paid visits to Mr Perkins, to Quincy, to Mrs: Greenleaf, and judge Dawes— Then call’d at Mr: Foster’s and found several letters— Dined with Mr: Quincy— Visits to Mr: Parsons who was not at home, but I saw his wife, and to Mr: Tudor— At 5 in the afternoon I call’d again at Mr: Foster’s, for Louisa and immediately return’d to Quincy.

Day. This has been one of the months of my life, in the course of which I have gone through the greatest variety of scenery. When it commenced we were still at sea— Since then I have landed at Philadelphia; parted for the first time since my marriage, from my wife— Travell’d on to New-York, and to this place, and enjoyed the luxuries of meeting all my old friends, after an absence of seven years— My mode of life has of course been altogether various.— I have resumed the practice of bathing and taking exercise before breakfast, which I found so beneficial last Spring.
